title: Accessibility
snippet: An accessible interface allows people to experience your app or game regardless of their capabilities or how they use their devices.

title: Inclusion
snippet: To help you design an inclusive app or game, consider the following goals as you review the words and images you use and the experiences you offer.

title: Privacy
snippet: People use their devices in very personal ways and they expect apps to help them preserve their privacy.

title: Branding
snippet: Consider choosing an accent color.

title: Layout
snippet: People expect familiar relationships between controls and content to help them use and discover your app’s features, and designing the layout to take advantage of this makes your app feel at home on the platform.

title: Spatial Layout
snippet: Play Avoid anchoring content to the wearer’s head.

title: Typography
snippet: Follow the recommended default and minimum text sizes for each platform — for both custom and system fonts — to ensure your text is legible on all devices.

title: Color
snippet: You may also want to use custom colors to enhance the visual experience of your app or game and express its unique personality.

title: Icons
snippet: Apps and games use a variety of simple icons to help people understand the items, actions, and modes they can choose.

title: Images
snippet: Use the following values for guidance; for additional scale factors, see Layout.

title: Motion
snippet: Not everyone can or wants to experience the motion in your app or game, so it’s essential to avoid using it as the only way to communicate important information.

title: Materials
snippet: Instead, use standard materials for elements in the content layer, such as app backgrounds.

title: Inputs
snippet: InputsLearn about the various methods people use to control your app or game and enter data.

title: Gestures
snippet: Although the precise movements that make up basic gestures can vary per platform and input device, people are familiar with the underlying functionality of these gestures and expect to use them everywhere.

title: Feedback
snippet: FeedbackFeedback helps people know what’s happening, discover what they can do next, understand the results of actions, and avoid mistakes.

title: Loading
snippet: Instead, consider showing placeholder text, graphics, or animations as content loads, replacing these elements as content becomes available.

title: Onboarding
snippet: Consider providing a collection of context-specific tips instead of a single onboarding flow.

title: Launching
snippet: If you need a splash screen, consider displaying it at the beginning of your onboarding flow.

title: Navigation And Search
snippet: Navigation and search Path controls Search fields Sidebars Tab bars Token fields and search

title: Searching
snippet: SearchingPeople use various search techniques to find content on their device, within an app, and within a document or file.

title: Modality
snippet: Presenting content modally can:Ensure that people receive critical information and, if necessary, act on itProvide options that let people confirm or modify their most recent actionHelp people perform a distinct, narrowly scoped task without losing t....

title: Alerts
snippet: Avoid using an alert merely to provide information.

title: Action Sheets
snippet: Developer noteWhen you use SwiftUI, you can offer action sheet functionality in all platforms by specifying a presentation modifier for a confirmation dialog.

title: Activity Views
snippet: People can edit the list of actions to ensure that it displays the ones they use most and to add new ones.

title: Sheets
snippet: When a nonmodal sheet is onscreen, people use its functionality to directly affect the current task in the parent view without dismissing the sheet.

title: Popovers
snippet: Best practicesUse a popover to expose a small amount of information or functionality.

title: Buttons
snippet: There are also many button-like components that have distinct appearances and behaviors for specific use cases, like toggles, pop-up buttons, and segmented controls.

title: Menus
snippet: Menus are ubiquitous in apps and games, so most people already know how to use them.

title: Toolbars
snippet: Best practicesChoose items deliberately to avoid overcrowding.

title: Tab Bars
snippet: Best practicesUse a tab bar to support navigation, not to provide actions.

title: Navigation Bars
snippet: Best practicesChoose items deliberately to avoid overcrowding.

title: Sliders
snippet: Consider supplementing a slider with a corresponding text field and stepper.

title: Steppers
snippet: SteppersA stepper is a two-segment control that people use to increase or decrease an incremental value.

title: Toggles
snippet: Best practicesUse a toggle to help people choose between two opposing values that affect the state of content or a view.

title: Pickers
snippet: Best practicesConsider using a picker to offer medium-to-long lists of items.

title: Progress Indicators
snippet: Because the duration of an operation is either known or unknown, there are two types of progress indicators:Determinate, for a task with a well-defined duration, such as a file conversionIndeterminate, for unquantifiable tasks, such as loading or syn....

title: Labels
snippet: The guidance below can help you use a label to display text.

title: Text Fields
snippet: Best practicesUse a text field to request a small amount of information, such as a name or an email address.

title: Text Views
snippet: Best practicesUse a text view when you need to display text that’s long, editable, or in a special format.

title: Lists And Tables
snippet: Apps and games in all platforms can use tables to present content and options; many apps use lists to express an overall information hierarchy and help people navigate it.

title: Collections
snippet: Avoid creating a custom layout that might confuse people or draw undue attention to itself.

title: Scroll Views
snippet: If you build custom scrolling for a view, make sure your scroll indicators use the elastic behavior that people expect.

title: Split Views
snippet: Typically, you use a split view to show multiple levels of your app’s hierarchy at once and support navigation between them.

title: Boxes
snippet: Consider using padding and alignment to communicate additional grouping within a box.

title: Gauges
snippet: For example, a temperature gauge can use text to identify the highest and lowest temperatures in the range and display a spectrum of colors that visually reinforce the changing values.

title: Charts
snippet: For example, people might use a chart to:Learn how upcoming weather conditions might affect their plans.

title: Rating Indicators
snippet: Rating indicatorsA rating indicator uses a series of horizontally arranged graphical symbols — by default, stars — to communicate a ranking level.A rating indicator doesn’t display partial symbols; it...

title: Segmented Controls
snippet: Single choiceMultiple choicesUse a segmented control to provide closely related choices that affect an object, state, or view.

title: Search Fields
snippet: Search fields can use a scope control as well as tokens to help filter and refine the scope of their search.

title: Sidebars
snippet: June 9, 2025 Added guidance for extending content beneath the sidebar, and updated iPadOS and macOS

title: App Clips
snippet: An App Clip Code tends to be the best way for people to discover and launch your App Clip because its distinct design is immediately recognizable, and people trust it to offer a fast, secure way to launch an App Clip.

title: App Shortcuts
snippet: Because App Shortcuts are part of your app, they are available immediately when installation finishes.

title: Apple Pay
snippet: Use Apple Pay in your app to sell physical goods like groceries, clothing, and appliances; for services such as club memberships, hotel reservations, and tickets for events; and for donations.

title: Carplay
snippet: CarPlay is designed for drivers to use while they’re driving.

title: Healthkit
snippet: After you receive permission, it’s essential to maintain people’s trust by clearly showing them how you use their data.

title: Homekit
snippet: It’s crucial for your app to use the terminology and object model that HomeKit defines, so that you can reinforce people’s understanding and make home automation feel approachable.

title: Icloud
snippet: Best practicesMake it easy to use your app with iCloud.

title: In App Purchase
snippet: In-app purchasePeople can use in-app purchase to pay for virtual goods — like premium content, digital goods, and subscriptions — securely within your app.

title: Machine Learning
snippet: In addition to providing familiar features like image recognition and content recommendations, your app can use machine learning to forge deep connections with people and help them accomplish more with less effort.

title: Maps
snippet: A map can also include annotations and overlays and show routing information, and you can configure it to use a standard graphical view, a satellite image-based view, or a view that’s a hybrid of both.

title: Nfc
snippet: iOS apps running on supported devices can use NFC scanning to read data from electronic tags attached to real-world objects.

title: Siri
snippet: When you use SiriKit to define the tasks and actions that your app supports, people can use Siri to perform them even when your app isn’t running.

title: Wallet
snippet: People use their cards and passes in Wallet to make Apple Pay purchases, track their orders, confirm their identity, and streamline activities like boarding a plane, attending a concert, or receiving a discount.

title: Augmented Reality
snippet: If your app includes features that require specific AR capabilities, or if AR features are optional in your app, don’t show people an error if they try to use these features on a device that doesn’t support them; instead, simply avoid offering the fe....

title: Game Center
snippet: Alternatively, you can also use GameKit to present this data within your own custom UI.

title: Live Activities
snippet: For example, the Live Activity of a food delivery app might display the time remaining until your order arrives; a sports app could provide live in-game information for their Live Activity; and a workout app could show real time fitness metrics and o....

title: Live Photos
snippet: Live PhotosLive Photos lets people capture favorite memories in a sound- and motion-rich interactive experience that adds vitality to traditional still photos.When Live Photos is available, the Camera...

title: Notifications
snippet: Before you can send any notifications to people, you have to get their consent (for developer guidance, see Asking permission to use notifications).

title: Shareplay
snippet: For example, you can use the shareplay SF Symbol to identify the content or experiences in your app that support SharePlay.

title: Sign In With Apple
snippet: Supporting Sign in with Apple lets people use the Apple Account they already have to sign in or sign up, and skip filling out forms, verifying email addresses, and choosing passwords.

title: Tap To Pay On Iphone
snippet: Before you can integrate Tap to Pay on iPhone into your iOS app, you need to work with a supported payment service provider (PSP), request the Tap to Pay on iPhone entitlement, and use ProximityReader APIs, either through the PSP’s SDK or by adopting....

title: Widgets
snippet: People can use widgets to organize and personalize their devices, quickly accessing the information and features they need.

title: Sf Symbols
snippet: You can use a symbol to convey an object or concept wherever interface icons can appear, such as in toolbars, tab bars, context menus, and within text.

title: Designing For Ios
snippet: In addition, people often want apps to use their personal data and input from the device’s gyroscope and accelerometer, and they may also want to participate in spatial interactions.

title: App Icons
snippet: Play iOS app icontvOS app icons use between two and five layers to create a sense of dynamism as people bring them into focus.

title: Home Screen Quick Actions
snippet: Avoid making unpredictable changes to quick actions.

title: Multitasking
snippet: People expect to use multitasking on their devices, and they may think something is wrong if your app doesn’t allow it.

title: Requesting Permission
snippet: \# https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/requesting-permission Content extraction failed. Please refer to the original URL for the latest information.

title: Settings
snippet: On some platforms, the system-provided Settings app can also include settings for specific apps and games, often letting people adjust whether the app or game can access location information, use device features like microphone or camera, and integra....

title: Designing For Macos
snippet: In the typical use case, the viewing distance can range from about 1 to 3 feet.

title: The Menu Bar
snippet: Use the same system icons to represent actions such as Copy, Share, and Delete, wherever they appear.

title: Dock Menus
snippet: Also consider listing a few of the actions that are most likely to be useful when your app isn’t frontmost or when there are no open windows.

title: Column Views
snippet: NoteIf you need to manage the presentation of hierarchical content in your iPadOS or visionOS app, consider using a split view.

title: Outline Views
snippet: Use a table instead of an outline view to present data that’s not hierarchical.

title: Combo Boxes
snippet: Use an introductory label to let people know what types of items to expect.

title: Disclosure Controls
snippet: Best practicesUse a disclosure control to hide details until they’re relevant.

title: Image Wells
snippet: People generally expect to choose these menu items — or use the standard keyboard shortcuts — to interact with an image well.

title: Path Controls
snippet: If you make the control editable, the menu contains an additional Choose command that people can use to select an item and display it in the control.

title: Pop Up Buttons
snippet: Best practicesUse a pop-up button to present a flat list of mutually exclusive options or states.

title: Pull Down Buttons
snippet: Best practicesUse a pull-down button to present commands or items that are directly related to the button’s action.

title: Token Fields
snippet: Consider providing additional ways to convert text into tokens.

title: Color Wells
snippet: Best practicesConsider the system-provided color picker for a familiar experience.

title: Panels
snippet: When the situation calls for it, a panel can also use a dark, translucent style to support a heads-up display (or HUD) experience.

title: Going Full Screen
snippet: Apple Vision Pro doesn’t offer a full-screen mode because people can expand a window to fill more of their view or use the Digital Crown to hide passthrough and transition to a more immersive experience (for guidance, see Immersive experiences).

title: Printing
snippet: If your macOS app has a toolbar, you might want to put a Print button there, too, but consider making it an optional button that people can add when they customize the toolbar.

title: Windows
snippet: Conceptually, apps use two types of windows to display content:A primary window presents the main navigation and content of an app, and actions associated with them.

title: Designing For Watchos
snippet: Because people wear Apple Watch, they’re usually no more than a foot away from the display as they raise their wrist to view it and use their opposite hand to interact with the device.

title: Complications
snippet: People often prefer apps that provide multiple, powerful complications, because it gives them quick ways to view the data they care about, even when they don’t open the app.

title: Watch Faces
snippet: If you use one of these faces in your configuration, consider offering a similar configuration using a face that’s available on Series 3 and earlier.

title: Digital Crown
snippet: On both Apple Vision Pro and Apple Watch, people can use the Digital Crown to interact with the system; on Apple Watch, people can also use the Digital Crown to interact with apps.

title: Digit Entry Views
snippet: Always use a secure digit field when your app asks for sensitive data.

title: Always On
snippet: Also, if you display rich images or large areas of color, consider removing the images and using dimmed colors.

title: Workouts
snippet: In contrast, people tend to use their larger or more stationary devices like iPad Pro, Mac, and Apple TV to participate in live or recorded workout sessions by themselves or with others.

title: Designing For Tvos
snippet: People can use a remote, a game controller, their voice, and apps running on their other devices to interact with Apple TV.

title: Focus And Selection
snippet: The exception is when automatic selection might cause a distracting context shift, like opening a new view.

title: Remotes
snippet: In addition to several specific buttons, the Siri Remote combines a clickpad and touch surface to support familiar gestures like swipe and press that people use to navigate tvOS apps, browse channels and content, play and pause media, and make select....

title: Top Shelf
snippet: The system defines several layout templates that you can use to give people a compelling Top Shelf experience when they select your app in the Dock.

title: Designing For Visionos
snippet: Use these characteristics and patterns to inform your design decisions and help you create immersive and engaging experiences.

title: Eyes
snippet: The visual feedback, or hover effect, shows people that they can use an indirect gesture like tap to interact with the element.

title: Immersive Experiences
snippet: Immersion and passthroughIn visionOS, people use passthrough to see their physical surroundings.

title: Spatial Layout
snippet: Play Avoid anchoring content to the wearer’s head.

title: Materials
snippet: Instead, use standard materials for elements in the content layer, such as app backgrounds.

title: Ornaments
snippet: The system uses ornaments to create and manage components like toolbars, tab bars, and video playback controls; you can use an ornament to create a custom component.
